audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.materials: Two short passages with related claims.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check; one synthesis sentence exit ticket.

learning_objectives: Identify each text’s claim and support.
Describe the relationship: support, qualify, or oppose.
Choose statements accurate for both texts.

structure.title: Cross-Text Connections
objectives: Chart claims in five words each.
Test candidate statements against both texts.

lecture_script.script: Read Text 1 and Text 2 for claims. Ask how Text 2 responds-supports, qualifies, or opposes-and select the statement true for both.
Text 1: trees cool streets. Text 2: shade lowers energy use. Together: cooling benefits with practical effects.
If a choice misstates either claim, it’s out. State the letter that fits both.

worked_example.passage: Text 1: A survey finds bike lanes increase shop visits. Text 2: Weekend sales rose after a new lane opened.
worked_example.question: Together, the texts suggest

options.B: bike lanes may boost nearby commerce
options.D: weekends are the only profitable days

worked_example.explanation: Both link bike lanes with increased shopping activity.

practice_set.passage: Text 1: Eight hours of sleep improved recall. Text 2: Naps improved afternoon alertness.
practice_set.question: What do the texts together support?

options.C: Sleep can aid memory and alertness

homework: Write one-sentence claim summaries for two paired texts and state the relationship.
Create one statement that both texts support; verify with quotes.
Complete four cross-text items and explain one elimination.
